Necessarily there was a point about Jesus' targetting of the money-changers and sacrificial animal merchants rather than anyone else.  It is true that pilgrims needed to be able to purchase the animals to fulfill their needs for sacrifial atonement at the Temple. What offended Jesus so much was that on the back of this logical service for pilgrims the Temple hierarchy had created a massive engine of profiteering which impoverished the people of Judaea in addition to the heavy burdens placed on them by Roman taxation and the direct predation of Herod and his family. In fact, this profiteering by the Temple hierarchy predated Herod, going back to the dynastic greed of the Hasmoneans when Judaea was briefly independent, who used the title of Chief Priest as their kingship, since the provincial governorship had been attached to the Chief Priesthood by Persia and then the Greek Seleucids. 
 
 Since they were not Kings as such, they used the Temple as their de facto tax-base, and set the temple animal provision and money-changing service up as a means of extracting income from the pilgrims. This meant that the poor were penalised in terms of access to God's forgiveness, and formal conferring of righteous-status. So the poor, especially the sick poor, were being punished for their misfortunes. Inability to pay for the appropriate sacrifices meant being shut out and despised as sinners. Hence Jesus' concern to offer his own direct declaration of forgiveness of sins, as well as the spiritual element of meaning alongside the economic prophecy within "blessed are the poor". 
 
 Secondly, it destroyed the holiness and mosaic-law purity of the priesthood at large, because it destroyed the divine distribution of income sources within
 the Law. According to Torah, when Canaan was given to the Israelites God distributed the land to the tribes and families so that none were without means of making a living, except for the tribe of the Levites, who were given no land at all. Instead, as the priesthood, they would have as their income the animals sacrificed to God by all Israel, after sacrifice. So everyone was provided for. For the hierarchy then to be selling animals prior to sacrifice, and making money out of taxing pilgrims by making them buy temple-only currency meant that they, and the senior priests in particular, were not only taking more than their share from the rest of the people, but that they were all in tacit breach of the law of Moses for failing to abide within a definition of Levite income found within the books of the Law. In effect, the higher the position: the more compromised, rather than the more holy. 
 
 Thirdly, the profit-making at the Temple, being the greatest and most lucrative market in the land (as opposed to at the Mediterranean sea-ports) had the side effect of accelerating concentration of land-ownership into the hands of a few dozen leading families. Certain senior priests became land-magnates not only selling animals to the pilgrims, but also buying the farms where lambs, calves and doves were raised. So not only were they extracting income from pilgrims, but they were helping expropriate them as well, in terms of the tribal ancestral land distribution - creating landlessness, leading to indebtedness and thence slavery. 
 
 These are the specifics about the wrongfulness of the market at the Temple in addition to the prophets' general condemnation of profitmaking and interest-charging per se regardless of kind, amount or location.
